awd_titl_txt: Understanding the evolution and transport of indoor bioaerosols
awd_abstract_narration:
Airborne transmission of pathogens is a global public health concern. The COVID-19 global pandemic highlights the urgent need to control the transmission of virus-containing bioaerosols generated via coughing, sneezing, and speaking. In spite of this need, indoor air transport of bioaerosols is not well understood, particularly the effect of aerosol size on pathogen transmission and infectivity. The goal of this project is to advance our understanding of bioaerosol transport, viability, and infectivity to minimize and mitigate the transmission and spread of airborne pathogens in indoor environments. To achieve this goal, researchers will: i) investigate microorganism decay in bioaerosols in controlled environmental chambers using two viruses and two bacteria as model pathogens; ii) evaluate the evolution and transport of bioaerosols in indoor air under different ventilation configurations; and iii) develop and validate a coupled transport and risk infection model to minimize the dispersion and transmission of bacterial/viral bioaerosols via indoor ventilation systems. The successful completion of this project will benefit society through the development of new knowledge to understand and mitigate the transmission of bioaerosol pathogens in indoor environments. Further benefits to society will be achieved through student education, training, and public outreach. STEM training will be enhanced through the integration of research findings into course modules, the participation of researchers in K-12 summer science camps, and a partnership with the Rolla, MO Public Library to disseminate the project findings to the public. 

Current Centers for Disease Control and World Health Organization guidelines do not consider the possible transmission of SARS-CoV-2 via the inhalation of virus-containing bioaerosols smaller than 5 microns. This is contrasted with past research with other pathogens demonstrating that the airborne transmission of small pathogen-laden bioaerosols can cause acute respiratory diseases. Thus, there is an urgent and critical need to improve our understanding of bacterial and viral bioaerosols in indoor environments. The goal of this research is to address this need and advance our fundamental understanding of the transport, dispersion, and infectivity of indoor bioaerosols. To achieve this goal, researchers will carry out an integrated experimental and computational research program using two model virus pathogens (MS2 and Phi6) and two model bacteria pathogens (Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus). Research in Task 1 will investigate the decay of bacteria and viruses in bioaerosols as a function of time, bioaerosol size, and environmental conditions (humidity and temperature) inside a controlled environmental chamber. Research in Task II will characterize the transport and dispersion of the bacteria/virus-laden bioaerosols in a large environmental chamber to simulate indoor air under different ventilation configurations. Research in Task III will develop and validate a computational fluid dynamics (CFD) model of indoor bioaerosol transport coupled with a risk infection model. Successful completion of this project will lead to new knowledge and tools that could be utilized to design and implement more effective ventilation strategies and systems to mitigate the transmission and infectivity of bioaerosol pathogens in indoor environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, researchers from the Missouri University of Science and Technology and the University of Miami focused on understanding the evolution and transport of bioaerosols in indoor environments. The aim of the project is to mitigate the airborne transmission of pathogens. The research addressed two main goals: studying the influence of aerosol size on the properties of airborne pathogens and investigating control methods to enhance indoor air quality.

The aerosol dynamics model constructed by the research team demonstrated that a considerable number of pathogens in respiratory particles remain in the air for over a minute, highlighting the necessity of designing efficient control methods to mitigate transmission risks. The project further investigated how the size of the bioaerosols containing the pathogens, as well as environmental conditions such as temperature and relative humidity, could influence the viability of the pathogens. Experiments were conducted using laboratory chambers to simulate indoor conditions. The findings show that pathogens contained in larger bioaerosols (above 2.5 micrometers) are more viable compared to those in smaller bioaerosols (below 2.5 micrometers). The project further examined how control techniques, such as filtration, ultraviolet germicidal irradiation, and ozone exposure, may affect pathogen capture and viability in bioaerosols. The results revealed that smaller bioaerosol particles (0.25 to 0.5 micrometers) are more vulnerable to ultraviolet germicidal irradiation and ozone treatments than larger particles (0.5 to 2.5 micrometers). Using the obtained results, the project also constructed a computational fluid dynamics model to simulate and optimize the transport, evolution, and control of the bioaerosols in the indoor environment. This research contributes to the interdisciplinary fields of biology, environmental engineering and public health by elucidating the size-dependent properties of bioaerosols. The methodologies deployed, including real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and online particle measurement, provide robust data for further analysis. These findings bridge gaps in knowledge regarding aerosol dynamics, particularly their role in airborne disease transmission, advancing both theoretical understanding and practical applications.

The outcomes of this project hold important implications for indoor air quality control, particularly in high-risk indoor environments such as healthcare facilities. The insights generated from this research can guide the design of ventilation systems to mitigate the spread of airborne pathogens. The project also contributed to education by integrating its findings into course materials and engaging students at various educational levels. Furthermore, public demonstrations at the Phillip & Patricia Frost Museum of Science effectively raised awareness about aerosol science and its critical relevance to the COVID-19 pandemic. Two graduate students, one from Biological Sciences and one from Environmental Engineering, received extensive training in bioaerosol collection and characterization, contributing to workforce development in STEM fields. By engaging in this research, students were challenged to extend beyond the boundaries of their core disciplines to achieve the project objectives. This interdisciplinary approach not only broadened their technical expertise but also equipped them with the skills necessary for future research across diverse fields.

The results of this project have been disseminated through various channels, including the publication of seven manuscripts to date, with several more in preparation. Findings were also presented at American Association for Aerosol Research Annual Conferences and incorporated into classroom teaching, such as Introduction to Environmental Engineering, Air Pollution Control Methods, Environmental Toxicology, and Issues in Public Health. Additional outreach efforts included lectures at local high schools, presentations in academic workshops, news media features, seminars, interdisciplinary campus talks, and guest lectures in multiple courses, fostering widespread engagement and knowledge sharing across diverse audiences.
